en: Excerpt from "The Vale of Remembrance to the Vale of Dreams"\nBy Kram Steelspine, Ceannard of the mines.
en-GB: Excerpt from "The Vale of Remembrance to the Vale of Dreams"\nBy Kram Steelspine, Ceannard of the mines.

en: We had heard rumors, and then most of the elven troops garrisoned in our Valley left through the Gates to meet a dire threat, yet with enough left behind to ensure that imperial law still reigned supreme! \nOn this direst of days, the sky broke, lightning fell again and again, and - worst of all - magic failed! I remember quite vividly the ashen face of our resident wizard, a young scion of a minor branch of House Airgetine, as he told Eldoril Sharp-Blade, the officer left in charge of the Vale, that mana had disappeared and that he wasn't even able to light a candle with his magic.
en-GB: We had heard rumours, and then most of the elven troops garrisoned in our Valley left through the Gates to meet a dire threat, yet with enough left behind to ensure that imperial law still reigned supreme! \nOn this direst of days, the sky broke, lightning fell again and again, and - worst of all - magic failed! I remember quite vividly the ashen face of our resident wizard, a young scion of a minor branch of House Airgetine, as he told Eldoril Sharp-Blade, the officer left in charge of the Vale, that mana had disappeared and that he wasn't even able to light a candle with his magic.

en: Eldoril Sharp-Blade, was a no-nonsense elven veteran who quickly realized that none of his contingency orders covered such an occurrence. Like every thrall, I was planning a rebellion against the imperial order. In the middle of the destruction wreaked by this Cataclysm, Eldoril made me realize that our fates were intertwined: Without magic, without the empire behind him, there was no way he would be able to compel us to behave like good little imperial thralls. On the other hand, some of his patrols had brought back the corpses of very dangerous-looking monsters, and his men had the equipment, discipline, and training needed to face such fearsome foes.
en-GB: Eldoril Sharp-Blade, was a no-nonsense elven veteran who quickly realised that none of his contingency orders covered such an occurrence. Like every thrall, I was planning a rebellion against the imperial order. In the middle of the destruction wreaked by this Cataclysm, Eldoril made me realise that our fates were intertwined: Without magic, without the empire behind him, there was no way he would be able to compel us to behave like good little imperial thralls. On the other hand, some of his patrols had brought back the corpses of very dangerous-looking monsters, and his men had the equipment, discipline, and training needed to face such fearsome foes.

en: If only it had been that simple… The young Airgetine wizard thought himself the equal of a master in wit, if not in power, and managed to convince his personal guard to follow him on a trek towards the imperial heartlands, away from the taint of this travesty of discussion with thralls. As Eldoril didn't want to pitch his troops against fellow elves, he let them go, with a heavy heart. It was the last we heard or saw of them.
en-GB: If only it had been that simple… The young Airgetine wizard thought himself the equal of a master in wit, if not in power, and managed to convince his personal guard to follow him on a trek towards the imperial heartlands, away from the taint of this travesty of discussion with thralls. As Eldoril didn't want to pitch his troops against fellow elves, he let them go, with a heavy heart. It was the last we heard or saw of them.

en: One year after the Cataclysm, I met my first humans. Eldoril was able to tell me they were not, as I had thought, enemies but rather refugees turned allies of the Empire. And what a sorry bunch they were: some elderly, children, women, not many fighting men among them, and they were following an old man, Egil Karst, decked in clothes the color of fire. This first winter had been more than dire, but somehow, the steep walls of our valley had shielded us, and we had room left to shelter those people, provided they could forage for their own food. At that, Egil Karst, the cleric of Arun, gave a little smile and, out of nothing, conjured up a feast for his followers.
en-GB: One year after the Cataclysm, I met my first humans. Eldoril was able to tell me they were not, as I had thought, enemies but rather refugees turned allies of the Empire. And what a sorry bunch they were: some elderly, children, women, not many fighting men among them, and they were following an old man, Egil Karst, decked in clothes the colour of fire. This first winter had been more than dire, but somehow, the steep walls of our valley had shielded us, and we had room left to shelter those people, provided they could forage for their own food. At that, Egil Karst, the cleric of Arun, gave a little smile and, out of nothing, conjured up a feast for his followers.

en: We were all dumbstruck, magic was returning… And yet, our few remaining arcanists confirmed they could not sense mana. Egil confirmed this, explaining that he was only a vessel channeling the mana offered by the gods so that his flock could survive. Those human gods were real, and their magic was functioning. And those humans were all skilled with their hands, not being used to having magic at their disposal for every single task. Soon, they weren't refugees anymore but valued members of our community, helping mend and repair with their hands and stone and wood, instead of with spells and mana.
en-GB: We were all dumbstruck, magic was returning… And yet, our few remaining arcanists confirmed they could not sense mana. Egil confirmed this, explaining that he was only a vessel channelling the mana offered by the gods so that his flock could survive. Those human gods were real, and their magic was functioning. And those humans were all skilled with their hands, not being used to having magic at their disposal for every single task. Soon, they weren't refugees anymore but valued members of our community, helping mend and repair with their hands and stone and wood, instead of with spells and mana.

en: Their expertise was welcome as our foraging parties couldn't wander outside the fortress walls anymore, as the weather and the monsters had redoubled their assault. By now, even the fiercest of the anti-Manacalon among my miners approve of our tentative partnership with their erstwhile guards, as they have shown us that, no matter what their faults, their courage more than makes up for them. \nI am Kram Steel-Spine, the foreman of the mine, speaker to the elves, and Ceannard of the mines. Ceannard I remain, but of the whole Vale of Coparann, as we have chosen to rename our enclave. \nStrike true, fellow miners!
en-GB: Their expertise was welcome as our foraging parties couldn't wander outside the fortress walls anymore, as the weather and the monsters had redoubled their assault. By now, even the fiercest of the anti-Manacalon among my miners approve of our tentative partnership with their erstwhile guards, as they have shown us that, no matter what their faults, their courage more than makes up for them. \nI am Kram Steel-Spine, the foreman of the mine, speaker to the elves, and Ceannard of the mines. Ceannard I remain, but of the whole Vale of Coparann, as we have chosen to rename our enclave. \nStrike true, fellow miners!

en:
In Solasta, you can craft various items. To do so, you need the proper equipment, ingredients, skill, and time. For magical items, sometimes you need to know spells.

Crafting is performed while traveling, once your party has set up camp but is not yet sleeping.

Characters can devote some of their free time to working on their current crafting task.
en-GB:
In Solasta, you can craft various items. To do so, you need the proper equipment, ingredients, skill, and time. For magical items, sometimes you need to know spells.

Crafting is performed while travelling, once your party has set up camp but is not yet sleeping.

Characters can devote some of their free time to working on their current crafting task.

en:
These are the tools required for crafting:

-Potions: Herbalism kit
-Scrolls: Scroll kit
-Poisons: Poisoner's kit
-Enchanted weapons and armor: Manacalon Rosary

You'll need to be proficient with these tools to use them.
en-GB:
These are the tools required for crafting:

-Potions: Herbalism kit
-Scrolls: Scroll kit
-Poisons: Poisoner's kit
-Enchanted weapons and armour: Manacalon Rosary

You'll need to be proficient with these tools to use them.

en:
Even if you're proficient with a given crafting tool, you'll still need specific skills to make successive checks against the recipe's DC.
To craft potions, sometimes Medicine is enough, but Arcana is very useful.
To craft poisons, Medicine or Nature is useful.
To craft scrolls or enchanted items, Arcana is a must.
en-GB:
Even if you're proficient with a given crafting tool, you'll still need specific skills to make successive checks against the recipe's DC.
To craft potions, sometimes Medicine is enough, but Arcana is very useful.
To craft poisons, Medicine or Nature is useful.
To craft scrolls or enchanted items, Arcana is a must.

en: Crafting requires ingredients. They can be found while adventuring, gathered from flowers, bushes and rocks, sometimes from dead creatures. \nObviously, you can also buy them from shops, unless they are very rare.\nEnchanting requires Prime items that have been magically prepared for enchanting by Manacalon master smiths, whose secrets have been lost with the Cataclysm. Generally, a Primed Item will require a very rare additional ingredient to fulfill its potential.
en-GB: Crafting requires ingredients. They can be found while adventuring, gathered from flowers, bushes and rocks, sometimes from dead creatures. \nObviously, you can also buy them from shops, unless they are very rare.\nEnchanting requires Prime items that have been magically prepared for enchanting by Manacalon master smiths, whose secrets have been lost with the Cataclysm. Generally, a Primed Item will require a very rare additional ingredient to fulfill its potential.

en:
Finally, to craft an item, you need to know which ingredients to combine. These "recipes" can be learned by reading manuals or taught by masters. 
Solastan factions generally keep copies of recipes and sell them at good prices to their friends, but some can be found out there in the Badlands, too.

Once a recipe has been learned, all the party can use it.
en-GB:
Finally, to craft an item, you need to know which ingredients to combine. These "recipes" can be learned by reading manuals or taught by masters. 
Solastan factions generally keep copies of recipes and sell them at good prices to their friends, but some can be found out there in the Badlands, too.

Once a recipe has been learned, all the party can use it.

en:
To start crafting, open a character's screen and click on the Crafting tab. Simply select a recipe that is available to start.
The progress bar will fill as you travel, and you will be notified 
when the operation is over, so you can launch another one if you want.
Remember that if you cancel a crafting operation, the ingredients are lost.

Also, as long as your characters remain unseen, they have advantage on attack rolls.

en: Surroundings, continued …castle architecture is of First Expansion style, with many repairs and additions. A standard founding plaque: "Caer Tenarion", built by the 25th Iron Legion in the 24th year of Gwaltrian the Third - year 1557 in the Manacalon calendar, or 1486 before the Cataclysm. Presumably built to pacify the surrounding area.
en-GB: Surroundings, continued …castle architecture is of First Expansion style, with many repairs and additions. A standard founding plaque: "Caer Tenarion", built by the 25th Iron Legion in the 24th year of Gwaltrian the Third - year 1557 in the Manacalon calendar, or 1486 before the Cataclysm. Presumably built to pacify the surrounding area.

en: Later, same day. My initial impression confirmed: the castle is occupied. I encountered a patrol of skeletons led by a wraith who gave his name as Adam the Twelfth, a former Imperial officer and now captain of the castle's guard. He questioned me closely and gave me permission to research outside the castle, but not to approach the castle or try to enter. The lord, whose name he gave as Mardracht, does not receive visitors. Indeed, the captain admitted that he himself had not seen or spoken with his master in several centuries.
en-GB: Later, same day. My initial impression confirmed: the castle is occupied. I encountered a patrol of skeletons led by a wraith who gave his name as Adam the Twelfth, a former Imperial officer and now captain of the castle's guard. He questioned me closely and gave me permission to research outside the castle, but not to approach the castle or try to enter. The lord, whose name he gave as Mardracht, does not receive visitors. Indeed, the captain admitted that he himself had not seen or spoken with his master in several centuries.

en: Graveyard, continued …no gravestone shows a burial date later than the Cataclysm: no new burials in more than a thousand years. Possibly all in the castle are undead, like their guards. Impossible to confirm since I am refused admission.
en-GB: Graveyard, continued …no gravestone shows a burial date later than the Cataclysm: no new burials in more than a thousand years. Possibly all in the castle are undead, like their guards. Impossible to confirm since I am refused admission.

en: Substantial mausoleum at far end of the cemetery, built in First Expansion style. Inscription over doorway names 25th Iron Legion. Presumably officers were buried inside (and possibly in catacombs beneath, if the building filled up over time) while lower ranks occupy the surrounding graveyard.
en-GB: Substantial mausoleum at far end of the cemetery, built in First Expansion style. Inscription over doorway names 25th Iron Legion. en: The following day, continued …as I continued to document the graveyard, a pack of wolves arrived from the north, led by a human man - or so he seemed. Met by captain and guards. Conversed for several minutes, manner guarded but not unfriendly. The captain pointed in my direction, clearly informing the man of my presence. No one in the group showed any interest in me.

en: Later, same day: An elven woman came out of the mausoleum, accompanied by several others: elves and humans, all apparently alive. They could not have entered the mausoleum without my seeing them. Two questions arise:
en-GB: Later, same day: An elven woman came out of the mausoleum, accompanied by several others: elves and humans, all apparently alive. They could not have entered the mausoleum without my seeing them. Two questions arise:

en: Another way into the mausoleum? Possible catacombs beneath - underground passage into the castle?
en-GB: Another way into the mausoleum? Possible catacombs beneath - underground passage into the castle?

en: 2. Living souls in the castle, yet no burials newer than 1,000 years? Two possibilities: life magically prolonged (necromancy? Fits with undead guard I encountered) and/or bodies not buried upon death (also compatible with necromancy).
en-GB: 2. Living souls in the castle, yet no burials newer than 1,000 years? Two possibilities: life magically prolonged (necromancy? Fits with undead guard I encountered) and/or bodies not buried upon death (also compatible with necromancy).

en: I watched from hiding as they explored the graveyard, apparently looking for something (me?). Extreme caution is indicated from now on.
en-GB: I watched from hiding as they explored the graveyard, apparently looking for something (me?). Extreme caution is indicated from now on.

en: …upstairs to try to speak with Mardracht about it, but Aksha said he was resting and had left orders not to be disturbed - as usual. She offered to pass on a message - so helpful! - but I know it will never reach him.
en-GB: …upstairs to try to speak with Mardracht about it, but Aksha said he was resting and had left orders not to be disturbed - as usual. She offered to pass on a message - so helpful! - but I know it will never reach him.

en: For all I know she's told him I'm dead. She may be planning to make it true. He's so shaken and addled from the Cataclysm, he'd probably believe her. She could have killed him already - he could have been dead for centuries - but no: his magical defenses are still in place. He must be alive.

en: If only I could reach him - free him from her influence - but I can't get past her and her ghouls. So frustrating! I need to arrange a sudden meeting with a wooden stake, but she's careful.
en-GB: If only I could reach him - free him from her influence - but I can't get past her and her ghouls. So frustrating! I need to arrange a sudden meeting with a wooden stake, but she's careful.

en: Adam's no help. He won't join me against Aksha without orders from Mardracht, which of course can't come because she's got him isolated. How blind is he not to see that - I'll never yield the castle to her, no matter what she does. While Mardracht lives, I have to keep trying to save him.

en: …searching the graveyard as usual. The dwarf was there - he always thought I didn't see him, but I did - but now he's a ghost. Adam said he was an Antiquarian, some sort of scholar, so I tried to control him and find out what he knows.
en-GB: …searching the graveyard as usual. The dwarf was there - he always thought I didn't see him, but I did - but now he's a ghost. Adam said he was an Antiquarian, some sort of scholar, so I tried to control him and find out what he knows.

en: I was over-eager, though, and he got away. An opportunity lost. He might know something that could help me get past Aksha and her ghouls and free Mardracht from her influence. Someday, somehow, I will get rid of her. I will.

en: Nightmares again. The battle, the Rift - Kaseinax with the Crown, bathed in power.
en-GB: Nightmares again. The battle, the Rift - Kaseinax with the Crown, bathed in power.

en: The humans. The gods - the gods! What are they? Why so powerful? Why couldn't we stop them? Why did they come?
en-GB: The humans. The gods - the gods! What are they? Why so powerful? Why couldn't we stop them? Why did they come?

en: Why haven't they come for me? They will, I know it. All of us who were there: they'll hunt us, kill us - maybe worse. I will be ready. I am ready. This old worm has a few tricks yet - oh, yes. We were as powerful as gods ourselves, once. The elves have forgotten, but once they knew. Yes, they did.

en: Why don't they come? Have these alien gods been destroyed already? Is it safe outside? Or is that what they want me to think? They won't lure me out - oh, no. Never.

en: Excerpt from "The Blood-Fang Invasion"\nBy Ceannard, 8th of his name.
en-GB: Excerpt from "The Blood-Fang Invasion"\nBy Ceannard, 8th of his name.

en: It all began as a series of raids, pinpricks outside our walls, attacks on caravans. Enough to worry us and elicit a response, but nothing more! Alas! it was a trick and the raids proved to be guided by a cunning hand able to predict our reactions with unerring accuracy.
en-GB: It all began as a series of raids, pinpricks outside our walls, attacks on caravans. Enough to worry us and elicit a response, but nothing more! Alas! it was a trick and the raids proved to be guided by a cunning hand able to predict our reactions with unerring accuracy.

en: And so the force we sent after the raiders got wiped out, almost to the last man. It was more than a raid from an orcish clan; it was a full invasion aimed at conquering our vale! We were almost surprised at the gates, but managed to close them in time! We had lost our finest but our walls were strong and we were able to produce weapons to replenish our depleted arrows and bolt stocks quite fast. This siege gave us pause, as we didn't quite understand its purpose. The only access to the Vale of Coparann goes through the pass blocked by our town and the fortress. The vale itself is only easily accessible if you can fly! Otherwise, the steep walls provide as fine a natural defense as I have ever seen!
en-GB: And so the force we sent after the raiders got wiped out, almost to the last man. It was more than a raid from an orcish clan; it was a full invasion aimed at conquering our vale! We were almost surprised at the gates, but managed to close them in time! We had lost our finest but our walls were strong and we were able to produce weapons to replenish our depleted arrows and bolt stocks quite fast. This siege gave us pause, as we didn't quite understand its purpose. The only access to the Vale of Coparann goes through the pass blocked by our town and the fortress. The vale itself is only easily accessible if you can fly! Otherwise, the steep walls provide as fine a natural defence as I have ever seen!

en: And yet, they were so numerous that our numbers began to slowly dwindle, and we started to realize that we wouldn't make it on our own! And so I sent for my childhood friend, Joris Nikannen, using magical and also more mundane messengers to relay our plight!
en-GB: And yet, they were so numerous that our numbers began to slowly dwindle, and we started to realise that we wouldn't make it on our own! And so I sent for my childhood friend, Joris Nikannen, using magical and also more mundane messengers to relay our plight!

en: Two weeks later, the orcs managed to break through our defenses and reach the inner court! The hour was dire and all able to bear arms were manning hastily erected barricades, as it was only a matter of time till the phalanx at the gate was worn down! And it was in that instance that Gromnir Stonefist and his mercenaries hit the enemy's rear! Fierce was his assault, but cunning too. A series of hit-and-run strikes from many directions, fireballs and lightning bolts exploding, and coming from what seemed like a thousand voices, war cries from known units of the Principality of Masgarth! The orcs thought the rescuers far more numerous than they were, and Captain Stonefist managed to strike hardest at the command group of the orcs, killing the blood shaman who was keeping the clans together. It broke their spirit! We had won, but the cost was great and the feeling in my mouth was mixed! Joris Nikannen saw it and found the words to shake me out of my gloom!

And it was in that instance that Gromnir Stonefist and his mercenaries hit the enemy's rear! Fierce was his assault, but cunning too. A series of hit-and-run strikes from many directions, fireballs and lightning bolts exploding, and coming from what seemed like a thousand voices, war cries from known units of the Principality of Masgarth! The orcs thought the rescuers far more numerous than they were, and Captain Stonefist managed to strike hardest at the command group of the orcs, killing the blood shaman who was keeping the clans together. It broke their spirit! We had won, but the cost was great and the feeling in my mouth was mixed! Joris Nikannen saw it and found the words to shake me out of my gloom!

en: Ceannard, you think its grim, and it is! But believe me, being on the losing side would be even worse, as the orcs would have slaughtered or enslaved us all, down to the last babes!\nCeannard the 8th - Chronicle of the Blood-Fang invasion

en: Charter of the Stonefist mercenary company
en-GB: Charter of the Stonefist mercenary company

en:
1 - In recognition to its help to Coparann, the Stonefist mercenary company is now recognized as a unit of the guard of Coparann!

2 - Captain Gromnir Stonefist shall henceforth be known as Baron Gromnir Stonefist, Protector of the Vale!

3 - Among the duties of the company, it shall leave enough troops garrisoned in our Vale to ensure its safety, albeit part of the company can accept mercenary contracts under the usual conditions of the mercenary guild, provided said contracts do not go against the interests of the Vale!

4 - Upon retirement, each member of the Stonefist mercenary company who so desires shall be granted a parcel of land in the valley, as well as help to build a farm! To this we deed no less than 10% of the land in the western valley!
Issued in Coparann, 1005 AC, validated by acclamation
en-GB:
1 - In recognition to its help to Coparann, the Stonefist mercenary company is now recognised as a unit of the guard of Coparann!

2 - Captain Gromnir Stonefist shall henceforth be known as Baron Gromnir Stonefist, Protector of the Vale!

3 - among the duties of the company, it shall leave enough troops garrisoned in our Vale to ensure its safety, albeit part of the company can accept mercenary contracts under the usual conditions of the mercenary guild, provided said contracts do not go against the interests of the Vale!

4 - Upon retirement, each member of the Stonefist mercenary company who so desires shall be granted a parcel of land in the valley, as well as help to build a farm! To this we deed no less than 10 % of the land in the western valley!
Issued in Coparann, 1005 AC, validated by acclamation

en: On the New Magic of Humans and Their Gods
en-GB: On the New Magic of Humans and Their Gods

en: An ancient-looking book, with the eight rings of the Arcaneum embossed into the cover.
en-GB: An ancient-looking book, with the eight rings of the Arcaneum embossed into the cover.

en: On the New Magic of Humans and Their Gods, and Its Particular Implications for Necromancy. By Alithariel Threanin, Postulant Junior Master of the Arcaneum, School of Necromancy. Academic Session of 3044, Imperial Calendar
en-GB: On the New Magic of Humans and Their Gods, and Its Particular Implications for Necromancy. By Alithariel Threanin, Postulant Junior Master of the Arcaneum, School of Necromancy. Academic Session of 3044, Imperial Calendar

en: As my thesis in support of my candidacy for the rank of Junior Master of the Arcaneum at the School of Necromancy, I respectfully submit the results of my research into the nature and types of new magics brought to Solasta by the humans of Tirmar, in particular the effectiveness of those whom they call "clerics" in repelling and destroying undead creatures. This knowledge is of urgent importance as we struggle to understand these humans, and assess both the severity of the threat they may post to the Empire and the potential benefit they could bring to it once conquered.
en-GB: As my thesis in support of my candidacy for the rank of Junior Master of the Arcaneum at the School of Necromancy, I respectfully submit the results of my research into the nature and types of new magics brought to Solasta by the humans of Tirmar, in particular the effectiveness of those whom they call "clerics" in repelling and destroying undead creatures. This knowledge is of urgent importance as we struggle to understand these humans, and assess both the severity of the threat they may post to the Empire and the potential benefit they could bring to it once conquered.

en: It is widely known that the magic of humans derives from the entities they call "gods" ("goddesses" in the feminine, and "deities" collectively). I call it "divine magic" in this thesis, to distinguish it from our own arcane magic that is the result of magical study. Just as arcane magic is organized into schools, some divine magic is comprised of eight areas of study, which the humans call "domains." Each deity typically provides its clerics with access to two domains, representing its particular interests. The domain that corresponds most closely to the School of Necromancy is called the Domain of Oblivion.
en-GB: It is widely known that the magic of humans derives from the entities they call "gods" ("goddesses" in the feminine, and "deities" collectively). I call it "divine magic" in this thesis, to distinguish it from our own arcane magic that is the result of magical study. Just as arcane magic is organised into schools, some divine magic is comprised of eight areas of study, which the humans call "domains." Each deity typically provides its clerics with access to two domains, representing its particular interests. The domain that corresponds most closely to the School of Necromancy is called the Domain of Oblivion.

en: In addition to spells from two domains, a cleric has access to a wide array of other spells and powers, which are common to all regardless of their patron deity. Many are broadly similar in their effects to the spells of the School of Necromancy. There are two necromantic powers, though, that are completely new and unique: a cleric of any Tirmarian deity, if their rank is high enough, can repel undead creatures and even destroy them. The humans I have questioned believe that this is because their deities regard all undead creatures as "unnatural" - a word that reveals much about their primitive level of sophistication - and therefore undesirable, but they seem to know nothing about the means by which this result is achieved, speaking only about the "will" or "power" of their deities.
en-GB: In addition to spells from two domains, a cleric has access to a wide array of other spells and powers, which are common to all regardless of their patron deity. Many are broadly similar in their effects to the spells of the School of Necromancy. There are two necromantic powers, though, that are completely new and unique: a cleric of any Tirmarian deity, if their rank is high enough, can repel undead creatures and even destroy them. The humans I have questioned believe that this is because their deities regard all undead creatures as "unnatural" - a word that reveals much about their primitive level of sophistication - and therefore undesirable, but they seem to know nothing about the means by which this result is achieved, speaking only about the "will" or "power" of their deities.

en: The following pages examine the phenomenon of "turning" and destroying undead using both the classical thaumatological approach of Fathirien and her successors, and the more modern methods championed by Gorlindrien and the Practicalists. All conclusions are tentative. If this thesis is accepted, I propose to make this phenomenon my primary research topic.
en-GB: The following pages examine the phenomenon of "turning" and destroying undead using both the classical thaumatological approach of Fathirien and her successors, and the more modern methods championed by Gorlindrien and the Practicalists. All conclusions are tentative. If this thesis is accepted, I propose to make this phenomenon my primary research topic.

en-GB: A page apparently torn from a book, crumpled and thrown on the floor.

en: …as the Soraks followed humanity, a high priest of Oblivion succumbed to despair and madness. He tainted the peace of the grave with the uncleanliness of undeath, raising the fallen to muster an army. As he knew this was not a prayer that would gain the favor of Maraike, the lady of life and death, he and his followers couched their plan in the form of a curse instead, tricking their goddess into ensuring that their plan would succeed. Maraike granted their plea, but was not deceived. She cursed the conspirators as well, for they had been corrupted by evil and were denied her grace. They became the fallen, and those they raised from death became sorrow zombies, named after the curse of sorrow that they had wrought.
en-GB: …as the Soraks followed humanity, a high priest of Oblivion succumbed to despair and madness. He tainted the peace of the grave with the uncleanliness of undeath, raising the fallen to muster an army. As he knew this was not a prayer that would gain the favour of Maraike, the lady of life and death, he and his followers couched their plan in the form of a curse instead, tricking their goddess into ensuring that their plan would succeed. Maraike granted their plea, but was not deceived. She cursed the conspirators as well, for they had been corrupted by evil and were denied her grace. They became the fallen, and those they raised from death became sorrow zombies, named after the curse of sorrow that they had wrought.

en: Maraike's punishment ensured that none of the fallen could enjoy the touch of light without suffering and dying. They must forever skulk in the shadows until they repented. But Maraike's punishment was not all. Sorr-Tarr, the vile god of the Soraks, saw potential in the fallen. Without undoing Maraike's curse, he gave them powers to do evil: to corrupt others by their touch, and to create fouler servants than zombies. Of the original fallen not much is known, save that there were twelve of them, priests and paladins…
en-GB: Maraike's punishment ensured that none of the fallen could enjoy the touch of light without suffering and dying. They must forever skulk in the shadows until they repented. But Maraike's punishment was not all. Sorr-Tarr, the vile god of the Soraks, saw potential in the fallen. Without undoing Maraike's curse, he gave them powers to do evil: to corrupt others by their touch, and to create fouler servants than zombies. Of the original fallen not much is known, save that there were twelve of them, priests and paladins…

en: …the humans explained that they had fled to Solasta from their home, a world they called Tirmar, and that they were pursued by a race they called Sorr-Akkath or Soraks, which had spread across this world of Tirmar, and threatened to conquer all others.
en-GB: …the humans explained that they had fled to Solasta from their home, a world they called Tirmar, and that they were pursued by a race they called Sorr-Akkath or Soraks, which had spread across this world of Tirmar, and threatened to conquer all others.

en: The Governor received them with the appearance of kindness, reasoning that if they came as supplicant fugitives it would be an easy task to subdue them, and either set them to work as slaves alongside the inferior races of Solasta or bind them over to the wizards of the Arcaneum for dissection or whatever other form of study might prove most fruitful. When the guards sought to bind the humans, though, they called upon beings they called "gods," and manifested powerful magics that took their hosts by surprise. Thus they were able to escape.
en-GB: The Governor received them with the appearance of kindness, reasoning that if they came as supplicant fugitives it would be an easy task to subdue them, and either set them to work as slaves alongside the inferior races of Solasta or bind them over to the wizards of the Arcaneum for dissection or whatever other form of study might prove most fruitful. When the guards sought to bind the humans, though, they called upon beings they called "gods," and manifested powerful magics that took their hosts by surprise. Thus they were able to escape.

en: …deities of Tirmar are a source of a new and unknown kind of magic. The humans believe they are powerful entities, perhaps extraplanar in nature, whom they worship and whose commands they follow, receiving power in return.
en-GB: …deities of Tirmar are a source of a new and unknown kind of magic. The humans believe they are powerful entities, perhaps extraplanar in nature, whom they worship and whose commands they follow, receiving power in return.

en: The humans are careful to distinguish between "good" and "evil" deities. "Good" deities are those whom the humans see as helpful to them, and - in their theology at least - concerned with their welfare. "Evil" deities are those who are hostile to humans and support the efforts of other races to conquer them. It was an "evil" deity and his followers - one Sorr-Tarr and the race of the Sorr-Akkath, or Soraks - who drove the humans to try to escape their home world of Tirmar, they say. Their arrival on Solasta…

en: There was a time, very long ago, when dragons were the rulers of Solasta. They lived in the mountains, close to volcanoes which they loved for their heat - for nothing else was hot enough to incubate a dragon's egg. At that time the dwarves had not yet come up from below ground, being more rock than flesh, and the halflings remained in their swamps, far from anyone. And what of the elves? The elves were in and of the air, without physical form but existing as swirling currents of air and mana, one with magic and with the world.
en-GB: There was a time, very long ago, when dragons were the rulers of Solasta. They lived in the mountains, close to volcanoes which they loved for their heat - for nothing else was hot enough to incubate a dragon's egg. At that time the dwarves had not yet come up from below ground, being more rock than flesh, and the halflings remained in their swamps, far from anyone. And what of the elves? The elves were in and of the air, without physical form but existing as swirling currents of air and mana, one with magic and with the world.

en: Eventually, however, the elves tired of a life of pure spirit and wind. They took a physical form and began to build great spires and palaces, bringing the beauty of their thoughts into material being. The dragons feared them, and a great war ensued, pitting fire and magic against air and magic until the elves…

en: The supreme duty of the head of a household is the management of servants. This is more important even than the welfare of the family, because a household can survive internal strife and injustice, but it cannot survive a breakdown in discipline. Heed well the lessons of history, and keep thoughts of revolt from the minds of your slaves.
en-GB: The supreme duty of the head of a household is the management of servants. This is more important even than the welfare of the family, because a household can survive internal strife and injustice, but it cannot survive a breakdown in discipline. Heed well the lessons of history, and keep thoughts of revolt from the minds of your slaves.

en: Remember that no matter how intelligent and endearing they may seem, your non-elf slaves are animals, nothing more. Do not indulge them, but give them every day a new reason to fear your wrath and a fresh reminder that your power is absolute. It is not going too far, if you can afford it, to select one at random now and again for death by torture. As well as providing entertainment for your guests and an example for your children, this practice instils a healthy…

en: In memory of Hathirin Lithinel and the other members of the House of Lithinel, blasphemously and treacherously murdered, and their house burned by rebellious slaves in the year 2435. This plaque was cast from brass melted in a furnace fueled by the bodies of their faithless slaves, both living and dead.

en: The Great War against the Dragons
en-GB: The Great War against the Dragons

en: The dragons saw how the elves were changing the world, bringing beauty to blasted volcanic wastes, and living green to barren fields of rock. They had never seen beauty before, nor heard music; their language was devoid of poetry, and their magic was brutal and without wonder.
en-GB: The dragons saw how the elves were changing the world, bringing beauty to blasted volcanic wastes, and living green to barren fields of rock. They had never seen beauty before, nor heard music; their language was devoid of poetry, and their magic was brutal and without wonder.

en: The dragons fell in love with the elves, as all do who see them. They longed to possess them, for dragons are avaricious by nature. With sweet words and trickery they enslaved a few of the fair people, but most elves were not taken in by the dragons' flattery, and prepared to resist them.
en-GB: The dragons fell in love with the elves, as all do who see them. They longed to possess them, for dragons are avaricious by nature. With sweet words and trickery they enslaved a few of the fair people, but most elves were not taken in by the dragons' flattery, and prepared to resist them.

en: Great battles were fought, blade against flame, and magic against magic. Mountains were leveled, and land sank to make the Inner Sea. The tunnels where the dwarves hid in fear were flooded. It was in that bloody crucible that our people's mastery of magic was forged, and the elven race united under the first Emperor Ilmathir Ellanion.
en-GB: Great battles were fought, blade against flame, and magic against magic. Mountains were levelled, and land sank to make the Inner Sea. The tunnels where the dwarves hid in fear were flooded. It was in that bloody crucible that our people's mastery of magic was forged, and the elven race united under the first Emperor Ilmathir Ellanion.

en: The war against the dragons lasted for three generations before the warrior Empress Cythaeriel Ellanion, the Lady of the Bright Blade, led the elves to…
en-GB: The war against the dragons lasted for three generations before the warrior Empress Cythaeriel Ellanion, the Lady of the Bright Blade, led the elves to…

en: In memory of the Emperor Laethar Aerlinn, first of his name, who reigned from the year 1773 until 2117 and oversaw the glorious expansion of the Empire, subjugating the rebel elves of the forests, the dwarves of the western mountains, and the halflings. Hero of the Forest of Flames, where he slew more than a hundred rebels with his own hand. Treacherously slain by rebel arrows during the advance on Colthannin. And to his Queen Saefinala and his son Prince Kealin, both treacherously murdered on the orders of the usurper and false Emperor Rithian Thirion, who seized the throne.
en-GB: In memory of the Emperor Laethar Aerlinn, first of his name, who reigned from the year 1773 until 2117 and oversaw the glorious expansion of the Empire, subjugating the rebel elves of the forests, the dwarves of the western mountains, and the halflings. Hero of the Forest of Flames, where he slew more than a hundred rebels with his own hand. Treacherously slain by rebel arrows during the advance on Colthannin. And to his Queen Saefinala and his son Prince Kealin, both treacherously murdered on the orders of the usurper and false Emperor Rithian Thirion, who seized the throne.

en: This monument is raised by their faithful servants who brought forth their bodies from Siothyrnas to this place of refuge until such time as the dynasty of Aerlinn is restored and their sacred remains can return to the capital.
en-GB: This monument is raised by their faithful servants who brought forth their bodies from Siothyrnas to this place of refuge until such time as the dynasty of Aerlinn is restored and their sacred remains can return to the capital.

en: In memory of the 17th, 18th, and 19th Iron Legions, treacherously slain in the Forest of Colthannin by rebel elves. They shall be avenged. The sylvan elves will be brought to heel and their forest shall be destroyed, except for one tree where the bodies of their leaders will hang eternally for their crimes. This we swear.
en-GB: In memory of the 17th, 18th, and 19th Iron Legions, treacherously slain in the Forest of Colthannin by rebel elves. They shall be avenged. The sylvan elves will be brought to heel and their forest shall be destroyed, except for one tree where the bodies of their leaders will hang eternally for their crimes. This we swear.

en: In memory of Larithir Elirion, Prince of the Blood and Governor of the North, who fell in battle against the savage snow dwarves of the northern mountains. In his name they will be conquered.
en-GB: In memory of Larithir Elirion, Prince of the Blood and Governor of the North, who fell in battle against the savage snow dwarves of the northern mountains. In his name they will be conquered.

en: In memory of Fathiel Morvannion, Prince and General, who gave his life for the glory of the Empire in the crossing of the Falafyn River in the first year of the eastern campaign. His body rests with his comrades in arms, but those of his home town remember him.
en-GB: In memory of Fathiel Morvannion, Prince and General, who gave his life for the glory of the Empire in the crossing of the Falafyn River in the first year of the eastern campaign. His body rests with his comrades in arms, but those of his home town remember him.

en: In memory of Galatheriel Amaneithon, Lady of the House of Amaneithon and beloved mother. Raised by her grieving son, Helarioth Amaneithon, who was kept from the funeral by his duty in Hyfrynas. He vows to raise a monument to her from the bones of sylvan rebels.
en-GB: In memory of Galatheriel Amaneithon, Lady of the House of Amaneithon and beloved mother. Raised by her grieving son, Helarioth Amaneithon, who was kept from the funeral by his duty in Hyfrynas. He vows to raise a monument to her from the bones of sylvan rebels.

en: In memory of Malirion Etharel of the House of Etharel in this city, who rose to become overseer of grain for the province of Afon-Dwar. He was murdered by a dwarf slave. Take warning, and trust not.

en: …as Master Irillien of the Arcaneum wrote in his great work "On the Nature of Illusion and the Question of Reality," "Many illusions, if believed, are as effective as if they were real; conversely, some realities, if ignored, may be avoided. Which, then, is more valid? What, indeed, is real, or reality? Was our great Empire, and our rightful mastery of the world and all who dwell therein, not a dream, which is a form of illusion, before our Iron Legions and our arcanists made it real?"
en-GB: …as Master Irillien of the Arcaneum wrote in his great work "On the Nature of Illusion and the Question of Reality," "Many illusions, if believed, are as effective as if they were real; conversely, some realities, if ignored, may be avoided. Was our great Empire, and our rightful mastery of the world and all who dwell therein, not a dream, which is a form of illusion, before our Iron Legions and our arcanists made it real?"

en: There is some merit, therefore, in avoiding a distinction between illusion and reality, but regarding them instead as two poles of a continuum. Some things are entirely real, and some things are entirely illusory, but the numbers of each are far fewer than is commonly supposed. Most things lie somewhere in between, partaking of the natures of illusion and reality in differing proportions. Those who seek a true understanding of the nature of things, and the distinctions…

Although they vary in their finer details, many theories blame the deity Sorr-Tarr, from whom the humans and their gods were fleeing as they entered Solasta. The scholars of the Arcaneum do not fully understand the class of beings called "gods" or "deities," and while their human followers proudly assert that their powers are without limit, it is clear that this cannot be the case, or the Cataclysm would have been prevented. Still, this Sorr-Tarr, being a powerful entity of this class, might have sought to open the Rift wider, in order to facilitate the pursuit by his Sorr-Akkath followers and complete…

en-GB: On Those Who Came from Tirmar

en: …humans and Sorr-Akkath are thought to be the only mortal beings to cross from Tirmar, the question of orcs and their kin must be taken into account. Human accounts of the matter are confused and often contradict each other, but a careful reading of the best sources suggests that the orcs were once human, and were altered by the wild magics that accompanied the closing of the Rift.
en-GB: …humans and Sorr-Akkath are thought to be the only mortal beings to cross from Tirmar, the question of orcs and their kin must be taken into account. Human accounts of the matter are confused and often contradict each other, but a careful reading of the best sources suggests that the orcs were once human, and were altered by the wild magics that accompanied the closing of the Rift.

en: The human ancestors of the orcs were members of wild barbarian tribes from the more remote parts of Tirmar. Ferocity and courage in battle were the highest values in their culture, so when the forces of our two worlds combined at the Battle of the Rift, it was these tribes who sought out the most dangerous locations in order to win the most glory by the values of their culture. This brought them very close to the Rift itself, and therefore made them most vulnerable to the unpredictable magical energies that flared out from it. All of those who fought beside them perished, even the elite of the Iron Legions - but somehow these barbarians, strong of mind and strong of body, were able to survive. However, their bodies and minds were both affected, and they became the first orcs to exist in both worlds.

Ferocity and courage in battle were the highest values in their culture, so when the forces of our two worlds combined at the Battle of the Rift, it was these tribes who sought out the most dangerous locations in order to win the most glory by the values of their culture. This brought them very close to the Rift itself, and therefore made them most vulnerable to the unpredictable magical energies that flared out from it. All of those who fought beside them perished, even the elite of the Iron Legions - but somehow these barbarians, strong of mind and strong of body, were able to survive. However, their bodies and minds were both affected, and they became the first orcs to exist in both worlds.

en:
Hey there folks! Welcome to Solasta - or more specifically, the Early Access of Solasta: Crown of the Magister. We really appreciate your support. You're all fantastic!

Please bear in mind that you are playing an Early Access version of Solasta: Crown of the Magister which is still under development. This Early Access version contains around 10 hours of gameplay and gives you access to the full Character Creation Tool with all ancestries, classes, and archetypes unlocked, with a maximum level cap at level 6. The full 1.0 release will see a price increase and will deliver the entire main campaign of Solasta: Crown of the Magister, as well as many side quests for you to discover. 

We have done our best to provide a strong and enjoyable experience. However, do note that the Early Access version may contain some occasional bugs. You are warmly invited to send us feedback, report any bugs and problems, or suggest improvements on our Discord server (https://discord.com/invite/uu8utaF) as well on our official forums (https://forums.solasta-game.com/). Our goal is to continue working hand in hand with our players to make a game that is representative of what our community wants. Be sure that our team is currently working hard to release the full version of the Solasta: Crown of the Magister video game that will include lots of additional features and content. 

Considering the fact that game development is a very iterative process, please understand that your save files on the Early Access version will likely be incompatible with larger updates and with the full game release. As such, if you are looking for the complete experience the full version of Solasta: Crown of the Magister can offer, we encourage you not to purchase this Early Access version, but to wait for the release of the full game. Alright, enough reading - go and enjoy the game!

en: You can use an action to speak the horn's Command Word and then blow the horn, which emits a thunderous blast in a 30-foot cone that is audible 600 feet away. Each creature in the cone must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5d6 thunder damage and is deafened for 1 minute. en:
Draft of Biography
Memories of a Shadow Tamer
By A. Merton
1022 A.C.

They were only a handful of brave explorers, the first ever since the Fall, to cross the mountains to the Old Empire. Their names: Khay, Annie, Betty, Arwin, Swen, Rhianna, and Hector.
Together, they were stronger than all the monsters of the Badlands.
Long before the Copperhead Road was found, they knew the paths and tunnels from Masgarth to Manacalon.
They brought back an old book with teachings of how to enchant primed weapons, and sold it to a dwarf lord of the Gormsdottir clan. That was the start of it all. Soon, all eyes turned to the Badlands. The thirst for the forgotten secrets of the Old Empire was growing.

The rest is scribbled.
en-GB:
draft of Biography
Memories of a Shadow Tamer
By A. Merton
1022 A.C.

They were only a handful of brave explorers, the first ever since the Fall, to cross the mountains to the Old Empire. Their names: Khay, Annie, Betty, Arwin, Swen, Rhianna, and Hector.
Together, they were stronger than all the monsters of the Badlands.
Long before the Copperhead Road was found, they knew the paths and tunnels from Masgarth to Manacalon.
They brought back an old book with teachings of how to enchant primed weapons, and sold it to a dwarf lord of the Gormsdottir clan. That was the start of it all. Soon, all eyes turned to the Badlands. The thirst for the forgotten secrets of the Old Empire was growing.

The rest is scribbled.

en-GB: When you have cleared a location of monsters, go to any Scavenger outpost to report your deeds. They will send their people there to collect the minor loot left and sell it.\nEach time you visit a Scavenger HQ, you can claim the money they owe you.

en: They take about 20 percent of the total value of what they brought back. You also have the chance to buy back some of the collected stuff beforehand.\n\nYou don't have to talk to the Scavenger quartermaster to use the system, you can click on the sign nearby.

en: According to orc customs, both fighters must be unarmored and spells are prohibited, although other kind of powers can be used. The arena is protected against magic to ensure that no spells are used. Each combatant can pick a traditional set of weapons. Edrof never surprises and always chooses the two-handed axe. Pick a set of weapons to proceed to the duel. If you exit the arena, you will forfeit the battle in shame.

The arena is protected against magic to ensure that no spells are used. Each combatant can pick a traditional set of weapons. Edrof never surprises and always chooses the two-handed axe. Pick a set of weapons to proceed to the duel. If you exit the arena, you will forfeit the battle in shame.

I leave behind this dagger as a testimony to my enduring love and respect for my mentor, Adrasteia the Prudent Shield, Master of the Arcaneum.

en: The Ceannard is looking for heroes to investigate the Hall of the Hallowed Dead. Regular patrols of the Valley have shown that someone or something entered the Halls, and everyone in the Vale of Coparann is reluctant to enter the Halls. Find what is going on there.

en: Here lie the Hallowed Dead of the Silent Whisper. From the shadows they watched, from the shadows they whispered, and from the shadows they struck! Often enough, our enemies saw us come too late, thanks to the tireless work of the whisperers. Never in the light, save at the end, where they are remembered among the Hallowed dead, Fallen for the Empire!
en-GB: Here lie the Hallowed Dead of the Silent Whisper. From the shadows they watched, from the shadows they whispered, and from the shadows they struck! Often enough, our enemies saw us come too late, thanks to the tireless work of the whisperers. Never in the light, save at the end, where they are remembered among the Hallowed dead, Fallen for the Empire!

en: Here lie the Hallowed Dead of the Iron Legions. The might of the Legions was the mailed fist of the Empire. Like iron, they were forged. In the crucible of battle, they were tested, over and over again and never found wanting. Bravest of the brave, risking life and limb for the Empire, for their brothers and sisters, and for their honor, in the certainty that their deeds would be remembered in the chronicles of history and in the Halls!
en-GB: Here lie the Hallowed Dead of the Iron Legions. The might of the Legions was the mailed fist of the Empire. Like iron, they were forged. In the crucible of battle, they were tested, over and over again and never found wanting. Bravest of the brave, risking life and limb for the Empire, for their brothers and sisters, and for their honour, in the certainty that their deeds would be remembered in the chronicles of history and in the Halls!

en: Here lie the Hallowed Dead of the Arcaneum. Mana was the heart of Manacalon and none of the victories of the Legions were achieved without the help of the Arcaneum! Our Loremasters studied our enemies, our shock arcanists joined the fray! Even our court mages earned their place in the Halls with their selfless devotion to duty, often enough at the cost of their own lives!
en-GB: Here lie the Hallowed Dead of the Arcaneum. Mana was the heart of Manacalon and none of the victories of the Legions were achieved without the help of the Arcaneum! Our Loremasters studied our enemies, our shock arcanists joined the fray! Even our court mages earned their place in the Halls with their selfless devotion to duty, often enough at the cost of their own lives!

en: This ring belonged to Hyeronimus Bash, Lord Inquisitor of the Church of Arivad, before his god betrayed humanity. When that happened, Hyeronimus sealed this ring inside the temple, before joining the cult of Einar. Legend has it that Hyeronimus was the last man standing at the Battle of the Rift.

en: The Major Gate brought you to the heart of the Badlands, the Aer Elai. Unfortunately, the place is rather uncomfortable. Find a way out of this world of fire and lava.

en-GB: You found a possible escape route from the lava river, but it meant going head to head with a bunch of Soraks.

en: Find a Bone of the Magister
en-GB: Find a Bone of the Magister

en: You passed through a tunnel in the mountain, emerging in another insane place.

en: You arrived above a massive lake of acid, and the way to the Rift seems to be on the other side. Find a way to access the other side without falling to your death!

en: You finally found a way to cross the lake of acid.

en: It is here. The Rift still seems to exist, even if it is smaller. Obviously, the Soraks are doing all they can to reopen it. Approach carefully and plan your attack.

en: …head down, or I'm next on the menu.
en-GB: …head down, or I'm next on the menu.

en: What's worse, it looks like this is the only way out.
en-GB: What's worse, it looks like this is the only way out.

en: No other means of egress is apparent.
en-GB: No other means of egress is apparent.

en: They're camped right by the only exit? It just keeps getting better!
en-GB: They're camped right by the only exit? It just keeps getting better!

en: I just need to be patient. They can't stay there forever.
en-GB: I just need to be patient. They can't stay there forever.

en: Fine, then, I shall wait until they go. These creatures do hunt, right?
en-GB: Fine, then, I shall wait until they go. These creatures do hunt, right?

en: Guess I'm waiting them out. At least these rocks are… damned uncomfortable.
en-GB: Guess I'm waiting them out. At least these rocks are… damned uncomfortable.

en: Look at this size of this Council hall!
en-GB: Look at this size of this Council hall!

en: So this is what they spend our taxes on.
en-GB: So this is what they spend our taxes on.

en: Then who will administer the oath?
en-GB: Then who will administer the oath?

en: The maid who empties her chamber pot?
en-GB: The maid who empties her chamber pot?

en: The maid who empties her chamber pot? No, we're not as important as that. Perhaps her stable boy.
en-GB: The maid who empties her chamber pot? No, we're not as important as that. Perhaps her stable boy.

en: A lady like her wants nothing to do with drudges like us.
en-GB: A lady like her wants nothing to do with drudges like us.

en: There's an Oathkeeper for that, I think.
en-GB: There's an Oathkeeper for that, I think.

en: You thought it would be the Princess?
en-GB: You thought it would be the Princess?

en: No, in this chamber, she's just another delegate.
en-GB: No, in this chamber, she's just another delegate.

en: If she rules the whole Principality, who's more important?
en-GB: If she rules the whole Principality, who's more important?

en: Lady Kean, the Council's Oathkeeper, is trusted by all.
en-GB: Lady Kean, the Council's Oathkeeper, is trusted by all.

en: Very well. Pay attention. All of you.
en-GB: Very well. Pay attention. All of you.

en: My name is Leira Kean, Oathkeeper of the Council.
en-GB: My name is Leira Kean, Oathkeeper of the Council.

en: And I will be administering your vows.
en-GB: And I will be administering your vows.

en: Once sworn in, you will carry the authority of the Council wherever you go.
en-GB: Once sworn in, you will carry the authority of the Council wherever you go.

en: Your every action will reflect upon the Council's reputation. Remember that. Always.
en-GB: Your every action will reflect upon the Council's reputation. Remember that. Always.

en: Now, please, raise your right hands.
en-GB: Now, please, raise your right hands.

en: Do you, each and all, solemnly swear your lives and allegiance to this Council and promise…
en-GB: Do you, each and all, solemnly swear your lives and allegiance to this Council and promise…

en: …to carry out our mission to protect our alliance from those who would threaten the common good?
en-GB: …to carry out our mission to protect our alliance from those who would threaten the common good?

en: Excellent. Lord Carran will enter your name into Council's register. Thank you for your service.
en-GB: Excellent. Lord Carran will enter your name into Council's register. Thank you for your service.

en: What were you expecting? A parade?
en-GB: What were you expecting? A parade?

en: Were you hoping for a kiss from the Princess?
en-GB: Were you hoping for a kiss from the Princess?

en: I suppose you imagined something more pompous.
en-GB: I suppose you imagined something more pompous.

en: No. I don't know. It just feels a bit… anticlimactic.
en-GB: No. I don't know. It just feels a bit… anticlimactic.

en: Frankly, the speech was long enough for my taste.
en-GB: Frankly, the speech was long enough for my taste.

en: The formality reflects the solemnity of your oath.
en-GB: The formality reflects the solemnity of your oath.

en: But more would probably be… immodest.
en-GB: But more would probably be… immodest.

en: Stop wasting time! What's the mission?
en-GB: Stop wasting time! What's the mission?

en: As I'm sure you know, the Council maintains a number of outposts…
en-GB: As I'm sure you know, the Council maintains a number of outposts…

en: …to secure the border between the Principality and the Marches.
en-GB: …to secure the border between the Principality and the Marches.

en: One of them is the former Imperial Fortress, Caer Lem.
en-GB: One of them is the former Imperial Fortress, Caer Lem.

en: It is held by some fifty troops under the command of Captain Henrik.
en-GB: It is held by some fifty troops under the command of Captain Henrik.

en: He sends us weekly status reports - or rather, he used to.
en-GB: He sends us weekly status reports - or rather, he used to.

en: We haven't heard a word from him in three weeks.
en-GB: We haven't heard a word from him in three weeks.

en: Leave immediately for Caer Lem and find out if anyone there is still alive.
en-GB: Leave immediately for Caer Lem and find out if anyone there is still alive.

en: If Captain Henrik or anyone else is still breathing, bring them back.
en-GB: If Captain Henrik or anyone else is still breathing, bring them back.

en: The Council wants a first-hand report.
en-GB: The Council wants a first-hand report.

en: Wait - you spoke of the Marches?
en-GB: Wait - you spoke of the Marches?

en: A whole garrison, gone? There are only four of us.
en-GB: A whole garrison, gone? There are only four of us.

en: Just find out what happened. Run back if you get scared.
en-GB: Just find out what happened. Run back if you get scared.

en: Got it. Though we were hoping for a first mission with more riches than risk, if you catch my drift.
en-GB: Got it. Though we were hoping for a first mission with more riches than risk, if you catch my drift.

en: We hear ya. Just so you know, we'd like to start slow. Meaning more treasure. Less danger.
en-GB: We hear ya. Just so you know, we'd like to start slow. Meaning more treasure. Less danger.

en: You don't get to choose your mission, I'm afraid.
en-GB: You don't get to choose your mission, I'm afraid.

en: So gather what you need and go. Time is of the essence.
en-GB: So gather what you need and go. Time is of the essence.

en: Wait! These Marches - they're not in the Badlands, are they?
en-GB: Wait! These Marches - they're not in the Badlands, are they?

en: The Marches are a no-man's-land, between the civilized world and the Badlands.
en-GB: The Marches are a no-man's-land, between the civilized world and the Badlands.

en: It's outside the chain of mountains that really define the Badlands.
en-GB: It's outside the chain of mountains that really define the Badlands.

en: We wouldn't send you in there… yet.
en-GB: We wouldn't send you in there… yet.

en: What can you tell us about this Captain Henrik?
en-GB: What can you tell us about this Captain Henrik?

en: A fine officer. More than fifteen years in the Principality's army.
en-GB: A fine officer. More than fifteen years in the Principality's army.

en: He inspires trust, loyalty, and courage - hence the decision to post him there, facing danger.
en-GB: He inspires trust, loyalty, and courage - hence the decision to post him there, facing danger.

en: Right, I guess that's that. It's on to Caer Lem.
en-GB: Right, I guess that's that. It's on to Caer Lem.

en: Hello! How may I help you?
en-GB: Hello! How may I help you?

en: Mostly potions, for heroic adventurers like yourselves.
en-GB: Mostly potions, for heroic adventurers like yourselves.

en: I also have recipes for customers who like to craft their own.
en-GB: I also have recipes for customers who like to craft their own.

en: And ingredients too - even rare flowers from the Badlands.
en-GB: And ingredients too - even rare flowers from the Badlands.

en: Come back any time - I'm almost always open!
en-GB: Come back any time - I'm almost always open!

en: That's me! The one and only.
en-GB: That's me! The one and only.

en: What do you have to sell?
en-GB: What do you have to sell?

en: Everything you'll need for going out there into the Badlands…
en-GB: Everything you'll need for going out there into the Badlands…

en: …food, ropes, torches - and of course, armor and weapons.
en-GB: …food, ropes, torches - and of course, armour and weapons.

en: I also have some other stock, like remedies and antitoxins.
en-GB: I also have some other stock, like remedies and antitoxins.

en: They might come in handy. Ever heard of deep spiders?
en-GB: They might come in handy. Ever heard of deep spiders?

en: The inn? Well, it's not that old, but somehow it feels like it's been here forever.
en-GB: The inn? Well, it's not that old, but somehow it feels like it's been here forever.

en: You can meet all kinds of people here, that's the good thing.
en-GB: You can meet all kinds of people here, that's the good thing.

en: An old Scavenger, a diplomat from the Council, a knight, a lord, a beggar…
en-GB: An old Scavenger, a diplomat from the Council, a knight, a lord, a beggar…

en: We also have rooms to rent by the night.
en-GB: We also have rooms to rent by the night.

en: It's very old, from Imperial times. Perhaps a historian would know, but I don't.
en-GB: It's very old, from Imperial times. Perhaps a historian would know, but I don't.

en: Your beer is terrible, and that's being polite about it.
en-GB: Your beer is terrible, and that's being polite about it.

en: What? I've never had any complaints about the beer before!
en-GB: What? I've never had any complaints about the beer before!

en: Maybe your palate is not refined enough.
en-GB: Maybe your palate is not refined enough.

en: We'd like to stay for the night.
en-GB: We'd like to stay for the night.

en: Sure! Just walk up to the suite and settle in.
en-GB: Sure! Just walk up to the suite and settle in.

en: It's more like a large bedroom, really - but you know, this is the capital city.
en-GB: It's more like a large bedroom, really - but you know, this is the capital city.

en: No money, eh. No room, then.
en-GB: No money, eh. No room, then.

en: Stay in the light, my friends.
en-GB: Stay in the light, my friends.

en: Deputies? A word, if you please.
en-GB: Deputies? A word, if you please.

en: So famous already? I love it!
en-GB: So famous already? I love it!

en: You were in there, too. Are you a member of the Council?
en-GB: You were in there, too. Are you a member of the Council?

en: I'm Annie Bagmordah, Quartermaster of the Scavenger's guild.
en-GB: I'm Annie Bagmordah, Quartermaster of the Scavenger's guild.

en: We don't have a seat in there, but…
en-GB: We don't have a seat in there, but…

en: …they all know exploring the Badlands without us would be a bad idea.
en-GB: …they all know exploring the Badlands without us would be a bad idea.

en: That's why you should stop by our headquarters downtown.
en-GB: That's why you should stop by our headquarters downtown.

en: You'll need our services, I'm sure.
en-GB: You'll need our services, I'm sure.

en: No, but you'll find our services useful. Everyone does.
en-GB: No, but you'll find our services useful. Everyone does.

en: Did lord Carran not tell you?
en-GB: Did lord Carran not tell you?

en: No - he pretty much stuck to giving orders.
en-GB: No - he pretty much stuck to giving orders.

en: Ah, right. Anyway, we offer plenty of help and advice to beginners like you.
en-GB: Ah, right. Anyway, we offer plenty of help and advice to beginners like you.

en: We are grown-ups, you know. At least, most of us are.
en-GB: We are grown-ups, you know. At least, most of us are.

en: Of course you are. Well, good luck!

en: At least she's not another lady or something.
en-GB: At least she's not another lady or something.

en: Scavengers, eh? I never knew if they were legit or not.
en-GB: Scavengers, eh? I never knew if they were legit or not.

en: Inviting beggars to the Council? How peculiar.
en-GB: Inviting beggars to the Council? How peculiar.

en: I'd rather visit the temple, honestly.
en-GB: I'd rather visit the temple, honestly.

en: The Scavengers! They've seen so much already - the first explorers of the ancient empire!
en-GB: The Scavengers! They've seen so much already - the first explorers of the ancient empire!

en: So what do you think? Should we check out their headquarters?
en-GB: So what do you think? Should we check out their headquarters?

en: I've had enough talking - let's go kill some monsters!
en-GB: I've had enough talking - let's go kill some monsters!

en: If there's business to be done, we can't afford not to!
en-GB: If there's business to be done, we can't afford not to!

en: You piqued our curiosity. So - what exactly do you have to offer?
en-GB: You piqued our curiosity. So - what exactly do you have to offer?

en: What kind of help do you offer to people like us?
en-GB: What kind of help do you offer to people like us?

en: Simple. Now, people like you typically carry out missions for the Council…
en-GB: Simple. Now, people like you typically carry out missions for the Council…

en: …in the Marches, even the Badlands. Sometimes far away, like Captain Merran.
en-GB: …in the Marches, even the Badlands. Sometimes far away, like Captain Merran.

en: You really must be new. She's one of yours: Senior Deputy of the Council.
en-GB: You really must be new. She's one of yours: Senior Deputy of the Council.

en: Anyway - you trek out to some old ruin in the Badlands, kill a bunch of orcs…
en-GB: Anyway - you trek out to some old ruin in the Badlands, kill a bunch of orcs…

en: …well, you're still a bit green, so let's say goblins.
en-GB: …well, you're still a bit green, so let's say goblins.

en: Orcs will hurt more than your feelings, believe me.
en-GB: Orcs will hurt more than your feelings, believe me.

en-GB: So let's say you find yourself with a whole load of rusty swords, leather armour, shields…

en: …too much for you to lug back here.
en-GB: …too much for you to lug back here.

en: Oh - so we're puny as well as green? Thanks so much!
en-GB: Oh - so we're puny as well as green? Thanks so much!

en: So instead, you brave heroes just clear the place of monsters and draw us a nice, clean map.
en-GB: So instead, you brave heroes just clear the place of monsters and draw us a nice, clean map.

en: Then we take our carts and pick up every piece of junk…
en-GB: Then we take our carts and pick up every piece of junk…

en: …we bring it back, we sell it, and we split the profits with you.
en-GB: …we bring it back, we sell it, and we split the profits with you.

en: We move the stuff, you go off to kill more bad things, everybody wins.
en-GB: We move the stuff, you go off to kill more bad things, everybody wins.

en: What? You could never carry it all, anyway.
en-GB: What? You could never carry it all, anyway.

en: Do you know Arwin Merton, the so-called First Scavenger?
en-GB: Do you know Arwin Merton, the so-called First Scavenger?

en: Merton… it's a painful topic for me.
en-GB: Merton… it's a painful topic for me.

en: I'd rather not talk about him.
en-GB: I'd rather not talk about him.

en: No, we don't. There's a shop for that.
en-GB: No, we don't. There's a shop for that.

en: Say one of you gets killed out there in the Badlands.
en-GB: Say one of you gets killed out there in the Badlands.

en: Normally, you'd have to come back in a hurry to get them raised.
en-GB: Normally, you'd have to come back in a hurry to get them raised.

en: Instead, you tell us about your misfortune, and we'll go get your friend's body.
en-GB: Instead, you tell us about your misfortune, and we'll go get your friend's body.

en: We take it to a cleric we know, and praise be! He raises your friend from the dead.
en-GB: We take it to a cleric we know, and praise be! He raises your friend from the dead.

en: It's a flat fee, and very reasonably priced.
en-GB: It's a flat fee, and very reasonably priced.

en: Not a comfortable subject, I know. Perish the thought and so on - but it happens.
en-GB: Not a comfortable subject, I know. Perish the thought and so on - but it happens.

en: Well… it's risky, and clerics need pretty gemstones for these spells… but can you really put a price on peace of mind?
en-GB: Well… it's risky, and clerics need pretty gemstones for these spells… but can you really put a price on peace of mind?

en: Well, thank you. I guess that's it for us.
en-GB: Well, thank you. I guess that's it for us.

en: Fine. Feel free to visit us anytime. Or drop into any Scavenger camp.
en-GB: Fine. Feel free to visit us anytime. Or drop into any Scavenger camp.

en: By the way, if you find Captain Henrik, tell him we're still interested.
en-GB: By the way, if you find Captain Henrik, tell him we're still interested.

en: In getting our people to Caer Lem.
en-GB: In getting our people to Caer Lem.

en: The outpost is perfect for us. Close to the Badlands, with plenty of space for our camp.
en-GB: The outpost is perfect for us. Close to the Badlands, with plenty of space for our camp.

en: Right, we'll tell him if we find him.
en-GB: Right, we'll tell him if we find him.

en: The more you do for us, the more we do for you.
en-GB: The more you do for us, the more we do for you.

en: Oh? So this… business relationship can get better?
en-GB: Oh? So this… business relationship can get better?

en: And I hope it will, friend.
en-GB: And I hope it will, friend.

en: I guess we'll see you around, then.
en-GB: I guess we'll see you around, then.

en: Sure. Good luck out there, and don't forget - in the Badlands, always keep your eyes open.
en-GB: Sure. Good luck out there, and don't forget - in the Badlands, always keep your eyes open.

en: We're almost there… it's just up the hill.
en-GB: We're almost there… it's just up the hill.

en: It's a little too quiet, don't you think?

en: We're in the Marches, so quiet can't be trusted.

en: True. Let's keep our eyes open.
en-GB: True. Let's keep our eyes open.

en: Quite so. We must be on our guard.

en: Eyes up and hands on hilts, people. These are the Marches.
en-GB: Eyes up and hands on hilts, people. These are the Marches.

en: Hold formation, all! The Marches are full of perils.
en-GB: Hold formation, all! The Marches are full of perils.

en: Don't play the captain with me.
en-GB: Don't play the captain with me.

en: I'm just saying, be ready for anything.
en-GB: I'm just saying, be ready for anything.

en: Simply a suggestion. I meant no offense.
en-GB: Simply a suggestion. I meant no offence.

en: Damn right. Let's get on with it.
en-GB: Damn right. Let's get on with it.

en: All right. Let's just keep going.
en-GB: All right. Let's just keep going.

en: I have a bad feeling about this.
en-GB: I have a bad feeling about this.

en: Where's the garrison? Dead or run away?
en-GB: Where's the garrison? Dead or run away?

en: There's no one here. Not even corpses.
en-GB: There's no one here. Not even corpses.

en: Amazing! Classic Tirmarian architecture… I read about that, you know.
en-GB: Amazing! Classic Tirmarian architecture… I read about that, you know.

en: It just ended up here after the Cataclysm… incredible!

en: The Marches are full of stuff like this. The Badlands are worse.

en: I never saw a tower just stuck in a mountain like that.
en-GB: I never saw a tower just stuck in a mountain like that.

en: We're not in the Badlands yet, but that's a good introduction.
en-GB: We're not in the Badlands yet, but that's a good introduction.

en: Anyway, we have a mission. Let's check the fortifications.

en: Well, that's not a good sign.

en: Does this tell us anything we don't already know?

en: The blood isn't that fresh, but even vultures would have left some bones behind.
en-GB: The blood isn't that fresh, but even vultures would have left some bones behind.

en: There's enough blood here to suggest that the whole garrison was massacred.

en: Maybe it was the goblins… they took the soldiers and… ate them?
en-GB: Maybe it was the goblins… they took the soldiers and… ate them?

en: Well then, I'm out of ideas. Let's keep looking around.

en: Why did we take this job again? Oh, yeah… these lovely Council badges.

en: No one here to greet us? How rude! I was hoping for drinks, at least.
en-GB: No one here to greet us? How rude! I was hoping for drinks, at least.

en: This is no time for jokes.

en: Right. Whoever did this could still be around, and we don't want them hearing us.
en-GB: Right. Whoever did this could still be around, and we don't want them hearing us.

en: We should look for survivors. Fifty people can't just vanish.

en: It's a trap! The goblins killed everyone, and now it's our turn!

en: We need to get up to that door.

en: That won't be easy. These walls are falling apart.

en: If they slaughtered the garrison, they'll pay!

en: Is Captain Henrik there? We need to talk to him!
en-GB: Is Captain Henrik there? We need to talk to him!

en: Don't you dare speak his name, you filthy bastard!

en: They'll cast a spell on you!

en: Is something not right in there, or is it just me?

en: Lost their minds, the lot of 'em.

en: Clearly their distressing experience has affected their reason.
